Â reports its first quarter earnings on Thursday, July 25, 2013.Analysts are expecting Airgas to report earnings of $1.15 per share, up 2% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.13 per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has sagged from $1.29. Analysts are projecting earnings of $5.07 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $1.27 billion for the quarter, 1% above the year-earlier total of $1.26 billion. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $5.15 billion.For the last two quarters, the company has seen an uptick in revenue. In the most recent quarter, revenue rose less than a percent year-over-year to $1.26 billion. The quarter before that, it rose 5%.The company has been profitable for the last eight quarters, and for the last four, profit has risen year-over-year by an average of 9%. The biggest boost for the company came in the first quarter, when profit jumped by 21%.

3M
Â reports its second quarter earnings on Thursday, July 25, 2013.The Wall Street consensus is $1.70 per share, up 2% from a year ago when 3M reported earnings of $1.66 per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has fallen from $1.77. Analysts are projecting earnings of $6.71 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 3% above the year-earlier total of $7.53 billion at $7.77 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $31.03 billion.Revenue rose for the past two quarters in a row. In the first quarter, revenue increased 1% to $7.63 billion from the year earlier quarter. In the fourth quarter, the figure rose 4%.The company has been reaping profit in the past eight quarters, and for the last four, it has seen an average of 2% growth in profit year-over-year. The biggest gain came in the third quarter with a 7% surge.The majority of analysts (54%) rate 3M as a buy. That percentage is still below the mean analyst rating of its nearest nine competitors, which average 57% buys. Analysts are generally bullish on 3M, as seven analysts rate it as a buy and only one analyst rates it as a sell. Three months ago, these numbers were eight and one, respectively.

Canon
 reports its second quarter earnings on Wednesday, July 24, 2013.Analysts are projecting earnings of $2.50 per share for the fiscal year.Revenue has dropped in the past two quarters. In the first quarter, revenue was 23% lower than the year-ago figure. In the quarter before that, revenue fell 37%.While the company has been profitable for the last eight quarters, income has fallen year-over-year by an average of 27% over the past four quarters. The company weathered a blow in the fourth quarter when net income dropped 37%, marking the hardest-hit quarter.The majority of analysts (100%) rate Canon as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest four competitors, which average 30% buys. All two analysts rate Canon as a buy.

Advanced Micro Devices reports its first-quarter earnings on Thursday, April 17, 2014, and the consensus earnings per share estimate is zero cents per share.The consensus estimate has risen from three months ago when it was a loss of one cents. Revenue is projected to eclipse the year-earlier total of $1.09 billion by 23%, finishing at $1.34 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $5.75 billion.

column4: Analysts expect decreased profit for Clorox (CLX) when the company reports its first quarter results on Wednesday, October 31, 2012. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $4.29 per share. Revenue is expected to be $1.35 billion for the quarter, 3.4% higher than the year-earlier total of $1.3 billion. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $5.66 billion.The company has seen steady earnings for the last eight quarters, and for the last four, net income has increased year-over-year by an average of 87.6%. The company benefited from the fivefold growth in the second quarter of the last fiscal year, which was its quarter with the biggest gain.Analysts generally think investors should stand pat on Clorox, with 14 of 15 analysts rating it hold. The average analyst rating of the stock, has stayed constant from three months prior. The stock price has fallen 0.3% since July 30, 2012, from $73.04 to $72.81.

Unum (UNM) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, October 31, 2012.The consensus estimate is 77 cents per share, up 4.1% from a year ago when Unum reported earnings of 74 cents per share.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was 79 cents. Analysts are projecting earnings of $3.07 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 2.5% above the year-earlier total of $2.55 billion at $2.61 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $10.46 billion.

SCANA (SCG) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, October 31, 2012.Analysts are expecting SCANA to report earnings of 88 cents per share, up 8.6% from a year ago when it reported earnings of 81 cents per share.The consensus estimate has dipped over the past three months from 90 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $3.14 per share for the fiscal year. Analysts project revenue to fall 1.1% year-over-year to $1.08 billion for the quarter, after being $1.09 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $4.36 billion.Revenue has declined for the third quarter in a row. In second quarter, revenue declined 9.2% to $908 million while the figure fell 13.6% in first quarter from the year earlier and 9.7% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has been profitable for the last eight quarters, and for the last four, profit has risen year-over-year by an average of 7.6%. The biggest boost for the company came in the most recent quarter, when profit jumped by 28.6%.

Analysts expect higher profit for MetLife (MET) when the company reports its third quarter results on Wednesday, October 31, 2012. The consensus estimate is calling for profit of $1.28 a share, reflecting a rise from $1.11 per share a year ago.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has risen from $1.27. After being $20.46 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 16.2% year-over-year to $17.15 billion for the quarter. In the most recent quarter, net income rose by 85.5% from the year-earlier period. Net income rose 48.4% in the quarter before that, and 1309.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The majority of analysts (88.2%) rate MetLife as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest nine competitors, which average 52% buys. There has been a decrease in optimism about the stock among analysts over the last three months. Still, the stock price has risen to $35.65 from $30.65 on July 30, 2012.

In the month leading up to the Tesoro's (TSO) third quarter earnings announcement slated for Wednesday, October 31, 2012, expectations have risen for the upcoming results. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $31.43 billion.

MasterCard (MA) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, October 31, 2012.The consensus estimate is $5.93 per share, up 5.3% from a year ago when MasterCard reported earnings of $5.63 per share.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was $6.11. Analysts are projecting earnings of $21.88 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $1.94 billion for the quarter, 6.7% above the year-earlier total of $1.82 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $7.44 billion.The company has been profitable for the last eight quarters, but income has been falling for the last four by an average of 5.1% year-over-year. The hardest-hit quarter was the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, which brought a 95.4% drop.The majority of analysts (75.9%) rate MasterCard as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 55.7% buys. Analyst sentiment about MasterCard has waned during the last three months. Even so, over the past quarter, the stock price has increased from $441.15 on July 30, 2012 to $449.36.

In the month leading up to the Allstate's (ALL) third quarter earnings announcement slated for Wednesday, October 31, 2012, expectations have risen for the upcoming results. The consensus analyst estimate has gone from 82 cents per share to the current projection of earnings of $1.12 per share.The current estimate reflects a 600% rise from the year-ago quarter, when the company reported earnings of 16 cents per share.The consensus estimate has risen from 76 cents over the past three months. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $4.51 per share. A year after being $8.24 billion, analysts expect revenue to fall 15.7% year-over-year to $6.95 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $26.79 billion.

ITT (ITT) is expected to report poor third quarter earnings on Wednesday, October 31, 2012 with analysts expecting a 83.3% drop in earnings from a year ago. The consensus estimate is 39 cents per share, down from earnings of $2.34 per share a year ago.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 43 cents, but is unchanged over the past month. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.70 per share for the fiscal year. After being $2.98 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 81.9% year-over-year to $539.2 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $2.22 billion.For three quarters in a row, the company has seen revenue decline. The year-over-year drop in revenue was 81.2% in second quarter. Prior to that, revenue fell 79.1% in first quarter and more than fourfold in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year year-over-year.Analysts are split on ITT, but three of eight analysts rate it hold. ITT's average analyst rating hasn't changed over the past three months.

Dendreon (DNDN) is expected to book a wider loss than a year ago when it reports third quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 30, 2012 with analysts expecting a loss of 83 cents per share, down from a loss of 67 cents per share a year ago.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was a loss of 55 cents, but is unchanged over the past month. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting a loss of $2.67 per share. Revenue is projected to be 25.6% above the year-earlier total of $64.3 million at $80.7 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $325.4 million.In each of the last four quarters, the company has seen double-digit year-over-year revenue growth. Over that time span, revenue has increased by an average of more than threefold, with the largest growth in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year when it rose 708.4% year-over-year.The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Dendreon, with 12 of 18 analysts rating it hold. Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. Still, since July 27, 2012, the stock price has fallen 35.6% to $4.02 from $6.24.

DaVita (DVA) is hoping its third quarter earnings report on Tuesday, October 30, 2012 will help continue the momentum its stock price has enjoyed. Shares have risen 12.4% over the last three months to close at $110.82 on October 24, 2012.Analysts are expecting DaVita to report earnings of $1.56 per share, up 7.6% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.45 per share.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was $1.57, but is unchanged over the past month. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $6.13 per share. Revenue is expected to be $2 billion for the quarter, 10.6% higher than the year-earlier total of $1.81 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $7.91 billion.The profit dip in the second quarter came after three consecutive quarters of rising profit. Net income fell 4.7% in the second quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 48.3% in the first quarter, more than twofold in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and 13.4% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.The majority of analysts (81.8%) rate DaVita as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest six competitors, which average 75.7% buys. The average analyst rating of the stock has stayed steady from three months prior.

Wall Street is expecting higher profit for Allergan (AGN) when the company reports its third quarter results on Tuesday, October 30, 2012. Analysts are projecting earnings of $4.16 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 7.6% above the year-earlier total of $1.33 billion at $1.43 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $5.82 billion.

Optimism surrounds ONEOK (OKE), as it gets ready to report its third quarter results on Tuesday, October 30, 2012. In the month leading up to the Loews' (L) third quarter earnings announcement slated for Monday, October 29, 2012, expectations have risen for the upcoming results. Net income fell 5.6% in the first quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 3.2% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, 13.1% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 36% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.

's (SIAL) first quarter results in the month leading up to the company's earnings announcement slated for Thursday, April 25, 2013. The consensus analyst estimate has dropped from $1.02 a share to the current estimate of earnings of $1 a share.The current Wall Street consensus is 1% higher than the year-ago quarter, when the company reported earnings of 99 cents per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has fallen from $1.06. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $4.14 per share. Revenue is projected to be 1.2% above the year-earlier total of $665 million at $672.8 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $2.71 billion.The company has been reaping profit in the past eight quarters, and for the last four, it has seen an average of 0.8% growth in profit year-over-year. The company benefited from the boost in the most recent quarter when profit swelled 7.4%, marking the biggest gain.The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Sigma-Aldrich, with seven of 14 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

Republic Services
 (RSG) reports its first quarter earnings on Thursday, April 25, 2013.The consensus estimate is 40 cents per share, up 5.3% from a year ago when Republic Services reported earnings of 38 cents per share.The consensus estimate has decreased from 41 cents over the past month. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.90 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to eclipse the year-earlier total of $1.98 billion by 0.9%, finishing at $2 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $8.32 billion.Profit has fallen in each of the last two quarters. In the most recent quarter, profit dipped 33.5% year-over-year, and the figure dropped 21.1% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.A year-over-year revenue increase in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year snapped a streak of two consecutive quarters of revenue declines. Revenue climbed 0.2% in the most recent quarter. Prior to that, it fell 3.3% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 1.2% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.Analysts generally think investors should stand pat on Republic Services, with five of seven analysts rating it hold. Analyst sentiment has waned during the last three months.

After 

Southwest Airlines
 (LUV) took a loss of 2 cents a year ago, analysts think when the company reports this year's first quarter numbers on Thursday, April 25, 2013, the results will be a lot better. Analysts are expecting profit of 3 cents a share.The consensus estimate has fallen over the past three months, from 8 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of 98 cents per share. Revenue is expected to be $4.08 billion for the quarter, 2.2% higher than the year-earlier total of $3.99 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $17.86 billion.Over the last four quarters, the company's revenue rose by an average of 10.4% year-over-year. The largest growth was in the first quarter of the last fiscal year, when revenue climbed 28.6% year-over-year.The majority of analysts (61.5%) rate Southwest as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest eight competitors, which average 54.1% buys. Analysts have become more cautious about the stock in the last three months.

Range Resources
 (RRC) when the company reports its first quarter results on Thursday, April 25, 2013. Wall Street is high on Dunkin' Brands (DNKN), expecting it to report earnings that are up 16% from a year ago when it reports its first quarter earnings on Thursday, April 25, 2013. The consensus estimate is 29 cents per share, up from earnings of 25 cents per share a year ago.Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.52 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 5.3% above the year-earlier total of $152.4 million at $160.5 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $708.1 million.Revenue fell year-over-year in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, snapping the three-quarter streak of rising revenue. The 4% revenue decline in the most recent quarter can be compared with three quarters prior when it had been rising. It increased 5%in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, 9.8% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year and 9.5% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.The majority of analysts (55.6%) rate Dunkin as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest four competitors, which average 50% buys. The average analyst rating of the stock has stayed unchanged from three months prior.

CMS Energy
 (CMS), which is slated to report its first quarter results on Thursday, April 25, 2013. Analysts are projecting earnings of $1.65 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $1.85 billion for the quarter, 6.1% above the year-earlier total of $1.74 billion. It was in the most recent quarter that the company saw the biggest boost, a surge of 63.4%.The company's revenue has risen for two straight quarters. In fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, revenue increased 3.1% to $1.67 billion from the year earlier quarter. In the third quarter of the last fiscal year, the figure rose 2.9%.

The biggest drop came in the second quarter of the last fiscal year, when profit dipped by 26.1%.

(YHOO) reports its second quarter earnings on Tuesday, July 17, 2012.The Wall Street consensus is 20 cents per share, up 5.3% from a year ago when Yahoo! reported earnings of 19 cents per share.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's up from three months ago when it was 19 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.90 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 3.8% above the year-earlier total of $2.2 billion at $2.28 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $8.86 billion.The profit dip in the third quarter came after three consecutive quarters of rising profit. Net income fell 26.3% in the third quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 3.3% in the second quarter, 2.2% in the first quarter and 9.9% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.Most analysts think investors should stand pat on Owens & Minor, with three of six analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

It hasn't been adjusted since. Analysts are expecting earnings of $6.97 per share for the fiscal year. The largest gain for the company was seen in the most recent quarter, when net income swelled by 36.3%.

The majority of analysts (83.3%) rate United Technologies as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest eight competitors, which average 65.3% buys. Analyst sentiment has waned during the last three months.

In spite of an expected dip in profit, most analysts are positive about TE Connectivity (TEL) before it reports its first quarter earnings on Wednesday, January 23, 2013.Analysts are expecting TE to come in with earnings of 64 cents per share, 3% less than a year ago when it reported earnings of 66 cents per share.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 76 cents, but is unchanged over the past month. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $3.13 per share. A year after being $3.31 billion, analysts expect revenue to fall 3.3% year-over-year to $3.2 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $13.69 billion.Over the last four quarters, the company saw a year-over-year drop in revenue by an average of 2.3%. The biggest fall was in the second quarter of the last fiscal year, when it fell 6.4% from the year-earlier quarter.The majority of analysts (77.8%) rate TE as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest eight competitors, which average 53.1% buys. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

Wall Street is high on Motorola Solutions (MSI), expecting it to report earnings that are up 17.9% from a year ago when it reports its fourth quarter earnings on Wednesday, January 23, 2013. The consensus estimate is 92 cents per share, up from earnings of 78 cents per share a year ago.Despite not changing over the past month, the consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 93 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $2.76 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is expected to be $2.45 billion for the quarter, 9.7% higher than the year-earlier total of $2.23 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $8.71 billion.The increase in profit in the third quarter broke a streak of three consecutive quarters of year-over-year profit decreases. In the most recent quarter, profit increased by 60.9% year-over-year. Looking back further, profit dropped 47.9% in the second quarter, 68.4% in the first quarter and 37.2% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has seen revenue grow for three quarters straight. The 2.3% revenue increase brought the figure up to $2.15 billion in the most recent quarter. Looking back further, revenue increased 4.5% in the second quarter from the year earlier and 3.8% in the first quarter.
Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months. Consequently, over the past quarter the stock price has increased from $50.23 on October 19, 2012 to $57.95.

Shares of Waters Corporation (WAT) have climbed 12.1% over the last three months to close at $90.90 on January 15, 2013. The company is looking to keep that trend going when it releases its fourth quarter results on Tuesday, January 22, 2013.The consensus estimate is $1.58 per share, up 1.3% from a year ago when Waters reported earnings of $1.56 per share.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was $1.59. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $4.92 per share. Analysts look for revenue to decrease 0% year-over-year to $521.3 million for the quarter, after being $521.4 million a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $1.84 billion.For three straight quarters, the company has reported falling net income. Net income fell 2.1% in the third quarter. Going back two quarters, profit decreased 2.3% in the second quarter and 6.2% in the first quarter.Revenue was down in the third quarter after rising in the previous quarter. The 1% drop in the most recent quarter brought revenue down to $450 million. The quarter before that, revenue rose 0.9%.The majority of analysts (61.5%) rate Waters as a buy. That percentage is still below the mean analyst rating of its nearest seven competitors, which average 71.7% buys. Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months.

Expectations have dropped for Verizon Communications' (VZ) fourth quarter results in the month leading up to the company's earnings announcement slated for Tuesday, January 22, 2013. The consensus analyst estimate has dropped from 59 cents a share to the current estimate of earnings of 56 cents a share.Analysts are estimating a 7.7% increase from the year-ago quarter, when Verizon reported earnings of 52 cents per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has fallen from 59 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $2.42 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to eclipse the year-earlier total of $28.44 billion by 4.5%, finishing at $29.71 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $115.47 billion.The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Verizon, with 17 of 29 analysts rating it hold. Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. The stock price has fallen 8.3% since October 18, 2012, from $45.78 to $41.97.Verizon provides communication services and equipment, including wireless voice and data services, Internet access and broadband video One of Verizon's main competitors in the communications services industry is CenturyLink (CTL). Other competitors in the services sector include: AT&T (T), Sprint Nextel (S), and MetroPCS Communications (PCS).

Wall Street is expecting lower profit for Norfolk Southern (NSC) when the company reports its fourth quarter results on Tuesday, January 22, 2013. Analysts are expecting earnings per share of $1.19 after the company booked a profit of $1.39 a share a year earlier.The consensus estimate has dipped over the past three months from $1.34. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $5.27 per share. Analysts look for revenue to decrease 4.5% year-over-year to $2.67 billion for the quarter, after being $2.8 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $11.02 billion.Revenue dropped year-over-year in the third quarter, breaking the three-quarter streak of revenue growth. The 6.8% revenue decline in the most recent quarter can be compared with three quarters prior when it had been rising. It increased 0.3%in the second quarter, 6.5% in the first quarter and 16.9% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The last two quarters have seen decreases in the company's net income. In the third quarter, net income fell 27.4% from the year earlier quarter, while the figure dropped 5.9% in the second quarter.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) reports its fourth quarter earnings on Tuesday, January 22, 2013.The Wall Street consensus is $4.04 per share, up 7.7% from a year ago when Intuitive Surgical reported earnings of $3.75 per share.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was $4.09, but is unchanged over the past month. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $14.85 per share. Revenue is projected to be 17.6% above the year-earlier total of $496.8 million at $584.2 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $2.15 billion.The company has enjoyed double-digit year-over-year percentage revenue growth for the past four quarters. Over that span, the company has averaged growth of 25.4%, with the biggest boost coming in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year when revenue rose 27.6% from the year earlier quarter.In each of the the past three quarters, the company has seen its profits increase. The 49.8% year-over-year growth in net income in the most recent quarter came after the 31.9% profit growth in the second quarter and the 37.8% rise in the first quarter.

Wall Street is expecting lower profit for Texas Instruments (TXN) when the company reports its fourth quarter results on Tuesday, January 22, 2013. Analysts are expecting earnings per share of 33 cents after the company booked a profit of 41 cents a share a year earlier.Despite not changing over the past month, the consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 41 cents. Analysts are projecting earnings of $1.64 per share for the fiscal year. After being $3.42 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 13.7% year-over-year to $2.95 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $12.79 billion.The third quarter's profit growth came after a three-quarter streak of year-over-year profit declines. In the most recent quarter, profit increased by 30.4% year-over-year. Looking back further, profit dropped 33.6% in the second quarter, 60.2% in the first quarter and 68.4% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has seen declining revenue for the last four quarters. Revenue in third quarter was $3.39 billion, a drop of 2.2% year-over-year. Revenue dropped 3.6% in the second quarter, fell 8% in first quarter and 3% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.
The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Texas Instruments, with 17 of 34 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

A quality fourth quarter earnings announcement could push shares of Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) to a new 52-week high as the price is just 42 cents off the milestone heading into the company's earnings release on Tuesday, January 22, 2013.Analysts are expecting Johnson & Johnson to report earnings of $1.17 per share, up 3.5% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.13 per share.The consensus estimate has dipped over the past three months from $1.18. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $5.09 per share. Revenue is expected to be $17.67 billion for the quarter, 8.7% higher than the year-earlier total of $16.25 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $67.32 billion.The company has experienced a two-quarter streak of profit loss. In the most recent quarter, profit dipped 7.3% year-over-year, and the figure dropped 49.3% in the second quarter.A year-over-year revenue growth in the third quarter broke a streak of two straight quarters of revenue decreases. Revenue climbed 6.5% in the most recent quarter. Prior to that, it fell 0.7% in the second quarter and 0.2% in the first quarter.The majority of analysts (61.9%) rate Johnson & Johnson as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest nine competitors, which average 50% buys. Wall Street analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. Despite this, the stock price has fallen 0.2% to $72.37 from $72.52 since October 18, 2012.

Expectations have dropped for Parker-Hannifin's (PH) second quarter results in the month leading up to the company's earnings announcement slated for Friday, January 18, 2013. The consensus analyst estimate has dropped from $1.17 a share to the current estimate of earnings of $1.13 a share.Analysts' estimates are down 27.6% from the year-ago quarter, when Parker-Hannifin reported earnings of $1.56 per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has fallen from $1.57. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $6.39 per share. Analysts look for revenue to decrease 5.7% year-over-year to $2.93 billion for the quarter, after being $3.11 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $12.92 billion.A year-over-year drop in revenue in the first quarter ended a streak of revenue growth that had lasted three quarters. Revenue fell 0.6% in the first quarter and rose 0.1%in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, 4.7% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 8.4% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.The decrease in profit in the first quarter broke a streak of three consecutive quarters of year-over-year profit increases. Net income fell 19.3% in the first quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 3.3% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, 11.6% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 4.6% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.
Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

Wall Street is high on General Electric (GE), expecting it to report earnings that are up 10.3% from a year ago when it reports its fourth quarter earnings on Friday, January 18, 2013. The consensus estimate is 43 cents per share, up from earnings of 39 cents per share a year ago.Despite not changing over the past month, the consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 47 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.51 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is expected to be $38.71 billion for the quarter, 1.9% higher than the year-earlier total of $37.97 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $147.04 billion.The profit growth in the third quarter followed three straight quarters of falling profits. In the third quarter, net income rose 8.3% from the year earlier, while the figure dropped 17.5% in the second quarter, 11.6% in the first quarter and 17.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has seen revenue increase for two quarters in a row. In third quarter, revenue increased 2.8% to $36.35 billion from the year earlier quarter. In the second quarter, the figure rose 2.5%.
The majority of analysts (63.6%) rate General Electric as a buy. That percentage is still below the mean analyst rating of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 70.8% buys. The average analyst rating of the stock, has stayed unchanged from three months prior. Since October 17, 2012, the stock price has still fallen 7.8% to $21.12 from $22.91.

State Street (STT) is getting close to its 52-week high of $51.07 as it gets ready to report its fourth quarter results on Friday, January 18, 2013.The Wall Street consensus is $1 per share, up 7.5% from a year ago when State Street reported earnings of 93 cents per share.The consensus estimate has fallen over the past three months, from $1.02. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $3.85 per share. A year after being $2.54 billion, analysts expect revenue to fall 6.9% year-over-year to $2.36 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $9.55 billion.Net income increased in the third quarter, snapping a two-quarter streak of falling profit. In the most recent quarter, net income increased 21.4%. Going back two more quarters, the company saw profit decreases:4.5% in the second quarter and 9.3% in the first quarter.The company has seen dips in its revenue in the last two quarters. Revenue dropped by 5.4% year-over-year to $2.47 billion in third quarter. The quarter before that, revenue dropped 5.6%.The majority of analysts (71.4%) rate State Street as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 51.8% buys. Analyst sentiment about State Street has waned during the last three months. Still, the stock price has risen to $51.01 from $44.69 on October 17, 2012.

Analysts expect higher profit for SunTrust Banks (STI) when the company reports its fourth quarter results on Friday, January 18, 2013. The consensus estimate is calling for profit of 61 cents a share, reflecting a rise from 28 cents per share a year ago.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has sagged from 63 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $3.56 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $2.32 billion for the quarter, 2.4% above the year-earlier total of $2.27 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $10.57 billion.For three consecutive quarters, the company has seen its profits rise. In the third quarter, net income rose more than fivefold while it rose 54.5% in the second quarter and 38.9% in the first quarter.A three-quarter streak of falling revenue was snapped by the revenue growth in the third quarter. In the most recent quarter, revenue increased 63.3% year-over-year. Prior to that, revenue had been falling; it dropped 1.1% in the second quarter, 1.1% in the first quarter and 13.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.

Leading up to Morgan Stanley's (MS) announcement of its fourth quarter earnings on Friday, January 18, 2013 analysts have become more wary as expectations have fallen over the past month to earnings of 29 cents per share from earnings of 33 cents per share.The average analyst estimates earnings to come in at 29 cents per share, a reversal from a loss of 14 cents from a year ago.The consensus estimate has fallen over the past three months, from 35 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting a loss of 5 cents per share. Revenue is projected to be 0.9% above the year-earlier total of $7.01 billion at $7.07 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $27.07 billion.The company's reported revenue has declined in each of the last four quarters. In third quarter, revenue fell 40.7% to $6.83 billion. Prior to that, the figure declined 25.4% year-over-year in the second quarter, fell 10% in first quarter and slid 26.3% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.Analysts are split on Morgan Stanley, but eight of 22 analysts rate it hold. Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months.

Rockwell Collins (COL) reports its first quarter earnings on Friday, January 18, 2013.The Wall Street consensus is 90 cents per share, up 4.7% from a year ago when Rockwell reported earnings of 86 cents per share.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was 99 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $4.42 per share. After being $1.09 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 4.9% year-over-year to $1.04 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $4.63 billion.The profit drop in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year followed two consecutive quarters of increasing net income. Net income fell 13.1% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year while the figure rose 5.1% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 7.3% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.Revenue decreased in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, following a rise in the quarter prior. Revenue dropped 2.3% to $1.27 billion in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year from the year earlier. In the third quarter of the last fiscal year, revenue rose 1.3%.
The majority of analysts (60%) rate Rockwell as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest nine competitors, which average 50.5% buys. The average analyst rating of the stock has stayed steadfast from three months prior.

Analysts are looking for decreased profit for Johnson Controls (JCI) when the company reports its results for the first quarter on Friday, January 18, 2013. Johnson Controls reported profit of 60 cents a year ago, but the consensus estimate calls for earnings per share of 51 cents this time around.Over the past month, the consensus estimate has risen from 50 cents, but it's below the estimate of 63 cents from three months ago. Analysts are expecting earnings of $2.64 per share for the fiscal year. After being $10.42 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 1.7% year-over-year to $10.24 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $42.82 billion.A year-over-year revenue decrease in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year snapped a streak of three consecutive quarters of revenue increases. The 3.7% revenue decline in the most recent quarter can be compared with three quarters prior when it had been rising. It increased 2.1%in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, 4.2% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year and 9.2% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.The decline in profit in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year followed three straight quarters of year-over-year profit growth. Profit dropped 93.5% year-over-year in the most recent quarter. Going further back, the figure rose 16.8% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, 2.8% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year and 9.3% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.
The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Johnson Controls, with 13 of 21 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.

Despite an expected dip in profit, analysts are generally optimistic about Mosaic (MOS) as it prepares to reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, March 28, 2012.What to Expect:Analysts are projecting Mosaic to come in with earnings of 77 cents per share, down 36.4% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.21 per share.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was $1.25. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $4.74 per share.Revenue is projected to be 14.7% above the year-earlier total of $2.21 billion at $2.54 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $9.63 billion.Trends to Watch For:The company has seen double-digit year-over-year revenue growth for the past four quarters. Over that span, the company has averaged growth of 33.8%, with the biggest boost coming in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year when revenue rose 53.8% from the year earlier quarter.
The decline in net income in the second quarter snapped a three-quarter streak of increasing profit. Net income fell 39.2% in the second quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 76.7% in the first quarter, 63.9% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and more than twofold in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.Analyst Ratings:The majority of analysts (52.9%) rate Mosaic as a buy. That percentage is still below the mean analyst rating of its nearest seven competitors, which average 69.2% buys. Analyst sentiment has waned during the last three months.Competitors:Mosaic produces and markets concentrated phosphate and potash crop nutrients for the global agriculture industry. One of Mosaic's main competitors in the chemicals industry is PotashCorp (POT). Other competitors in the materials sector include: Agrium, Inc. (USA (AGU), CF Industries Holdings (CF), and Intrepid Potash (IPI).Recent Price Movement:

Paychex (PAYX) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, March 28, 2012.What to Expect:The Wall Street consensus is 37 cents per share, up 2.8% from a year ago when Paychex reported earnings of 36 cents per share.For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $1.51 per share.Revenue is projected to be 9.5% above the year-earlier total of $519.6 million at $568.9 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $2.24 billion.Trends to Watch For:For three consecutive quarters, the company's net income has increased. In the most recent quarter, profit increased 4.9% year-over-year. Going back two quarters, net income rose 12.9% in the first quarter and 2.9% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.
Analyst Ratings:Most analysts think investors should stand pat on Paychex, with 15 of 22 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more cautious about the stock in the last three months.Competitors:Paychex provides payroll, human resource, and benefits outsourcing solutions for small- and medium-sized businesses. One of Paychex's main competitors in the it services industry is Automatic Data Processing (ADP). Other competitors in the information technology sector include: CBIZ (CBZ), Equifax (EFX), and Insperity (NSP).Recent Price Movement:

UnitedHealth Group (UNH) reports its fourth quarter earnings on Thursday, January 17, 2013.Analysts are expecting UnitedHealth to report earnings of $1.20 per share, up 2.6% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.17 per share.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was $1.22. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $5.27 per share. Revenue is projected to be $28.2 billion for the quarter, 8.8% above the year-earlier total of $25.92 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $109.9 billion.The company's net income has been growing for three straight quarters. In the third quarter, net income rose 22.5% while it rose 5.5% in the second quarter and 3.1% in the first quarter.The majority of analysts (73.7%) rate UnitedHealth as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 43.6% buys. Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. Despite this, the stock price has fallen 7.1% to $52.82 from $56.88 since October 16, 2012.UnitedHealth Group provides healthcare services, including health benefit plans and services to national employers, non-employer based insurance options and health and well-being services for individuals aged 50 and older One of UnitedHealth's main competitors in the insurance (accident and health) industry is Cigna (CI). Other competitors in the financial sector include: Aetna (AET), Health Net (HNT), and Coventry Health Care (CVH).

Optimism surrounds Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), as it gets ready to report its fourth quarter results on Thursday, January 17, 2013. Analysts are expecting the company to book a profit of 17 cents a share, up from 14 cents a year ago.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has increased from three months ago when it was 16 cents. Analysts are projecting earnings of 68 cents per share for the fiscal year. A year after being $716.2 million, analysts expect revenue to fall 1.7% year-over-year to $703.8 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $2.77 billion.The company's profit has been growing for the past three quarters. In the most recent quarter, net income rose by 17% from the year-earlier period. Net income rose 4.7% in the quarter before that, and 21.2% in the first quarter.Revenue has declined in the past two quarters. In third quarter, revenue declined 0.8% to $745 million from the year earlier quarter. In the second quarter, the figure fell 0.9%.Analysts generally think investors should stand pat on Huntington, with 13 of 20 analysts rating it hold. Analyst sentiment has waned during the last three months.
Huntington's current dividend yield is 2.4% based on Thursday's close of $6.59. The company has an annualized dividend of 16 cents per share.

Wall Street is high on BB&T (BBT), expecting it to report earnings that are up 27.3% from a year ago when it reports its fourth quarter earnings on Thursday, January 17, 2013. The consensus estimate is 70 cents per share, up from earnings of 55 cents per share a year ago.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was 73 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $2.71 per share. After being $2.71 billion a year ago, analysts project revenue to drop 9.3% year-over-year to $2.46 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $9.75 billion.The company's net income has been growing for three straight quarters. The 35% year-over-year growth in net income in the most recent quarter came after the 68.7% profit growth in the second quarter and the 91.6% rise in the first quarter.Revenue has grown for three quarters in a row. In third quarter, revenue rose 10% to $2.68 billion while the figure rose 8.8% in the second quarter from the year earlier and 9.5% in the first quarter.

Whole Foods Market
 reports its fourth quarter earnings on Wednesday, November 6, 2013, and the consensus earnings per share estimate is 31 cents per share.Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.46 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $3.04 billion for the quarter, 4% above the year-earlier total of $2.91 billion. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $12.98 billion.The company's reported revenue has increased in the last three quarters. In the third quarter, revenue rose 5% to $3.06 billion while the figure rose 13% in the second quarter from the year earlier and 14% in the first quarter.The 26% profit increase in the third quarter positioned the company at its fourth straight quarter of double-digit year-over-year growth. Over that period, profit grew 30% on average, with the largest gain being a 49% surge in the fourth quarter.
column6: Forbes Earnings Preview: Whole Foods Market

column4:
After Lennar (LEN) took a loss of 6 cents a year ago, analysts think when the company reports this year's first quarter numbers on Tuesday, March 27, 2012, the results will be a lot better. Analysts are expecting profit of 5 cents a share.What to Expect:The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was 7 cents. Analysts are projecting earnings of 77 cents per share for the fiscal year.Revenue is expected to be $700.8 million for the quarter, 25.6% higher than the year-earlier total of $558 million. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $3.6 billion.Trends to Watch For:A year-over-year revenue increase in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year snapped a streak of three consecutive quarters of revenue declines. Revenue rose 10.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and fell 0.6% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, 6.1% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year and 2.9% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.
Analyst Ratings:The majority of analysts (53.3%) rate Lennar as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 29.2% buys. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.Competitors:Lennar is part of the homebuilding and real estate industry. It constructs and sells single-family homes and develops and sells residential land in the United States. It also invests in distressed real estate assets. Lennar also has a financial services wing that offers mortgage financing, title insurance and closing services for home buyers. The company was founded in 1954 and is based in Miami, Florida. One of Lennar's main competitors in the household durables industry is D.R. Horton (DHI). Other competitors in the consumer discretionary sector include: PulteGroup (PHM), KB Home (KBH), and Standard Pacific (SPF).Recent Price Movement:

In spite of an expected dip in profit, most analysts are positive about Walgreen (WAG) before it reports its second quarter earnings on Tuesday, March 27, 2012.What to Expect:Analysts are expecting Walgreen to come in with earnings of 77 cents per share, down 3.8% from a year ago when it reported earnings of 80 cents per share.The consensus estimate has increased over the past month, from 76 cents, but it's below the estimate of 84 cents from three months ago. Analysts are projecting earnings of $2.65 per share for the fiscal year.Revenue is expected to be $18.54 billion for the quarter, 0.2% higher than the year-earlier total of $18.5 billion. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $72.28 billion.Trends to Watch For:
The profit dip in the first quarter came after three consecutive quarters of rising profit. Profit dropped 4.5% year-over-year in the most recent quarter. Going further back, the figure rose 68.5% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, 30.2% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year and 10.5% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year.Analyst Ratings:The majority of analysts (52.4%) rate Walgreen as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 48.5% buys. Analysts have become more cautious about the stock in the last three months.Competitors:Walgreen operates a drugstore chain in the United States that provides consumer goods and services, and pharmacy, health and wellness services. One of Walgreen's main competitors in the food and staples retailing industry is CVS Caremark (CVS). Other competitors in the consumer staples sector include: Rite Aid (RAD), PetMed Express (PETS), and China Nepstar Chain Drug (NPD).Recent Price Movement:

Wall Street is optimistic about U.S. Bancorp (USB), which is slated to report its fourth quarter results on Wednesday, January 16, 2013. Analysts project a profit of 74 cents a share, a rise from 64 cents per share a year ago.The consensus estimate has dipped over the past month, from 75 cents, but it's still up from the consensus estimate of 73 cents three months ago. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $2.86 per share. Analysts project revenue to fall 8.9% year-over-year to $5.16 billion for the quarter, after being $5.66 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $20.29 billion.In each of the the past three quarters, the company has seen its profits increase. In the third quarter, net income rose 15.8% while it rose 17.6% in the second quarter and 27.9% in the first quarter.Analysts generally think investors should stand pat on U.S. Bancorp, with 15 of 28 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more cautious about the stock in the last three months.

Northern Trust (NTRS) reports its fourth quarter earnings on Wednesday, January 16, 2013.Analysts are expecting Northern Trust to report earnings of 75 cents per share, up 7.1% from a year ago when it reported earnings of 70 cents per share.The consensus estimate has dipped over the past three months from 78 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $2.88 per share. Analysts look for revenue to decrease 4.7% year-over-year to $989.9 million for the quarter, after being $1.04 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $3.94 billion.The company has reported increasing profit for three straight quarters. The 4.9% year-over-year growth in net income in the most recent quarter came after the 18.2% profit growth in the second quarter and the 6.8% rise in the first quarter.Revenue has declined in the past two quarters. In third quarter, revenue was $1.05 billion, 1.1% lower than the year-ago figure. In the quarter before that, revenue fell 0.2%.Analysts generally think investors should stand pat on Northern Trust, with 13 of 16 analysts rating it hold.

Leading up to Goldman Sachs Group's (GS) announcement of its fourth quarter earnings on Wednesday, January 16, 2013, analysts have become more bullish as expectations have improved over the past month from $3.23 per share to the current projection of earnings of $3.29 per share.Analysts are estimating a 78.8% increase from the year-ago quarter, when Goldman reported earnings of $1.84 per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has risen from $3.18. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $11.89 per share. Analysts look for revenue to decrease 2.3% year-over-year to $7.83 billion for the quarter, after being $8.02 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $32.58 billion.A three-quarter streak of falling revenue was snapped by the revenue growth in the third quarter. Revenue rose 81.6% in the third quarter and fell 10% in the second quarter, 13.5% in the first quarter and 22.7% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.Most analysts think investors should stand pat on Goldman, with 13 of 22 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have become more cautious about the stock in the last three months. Despite this, the stock price has risen from $124.50 on October 15, 2012 to $137.37 over the past quarter.

Optimism surrounds Accenture (ACN), as it gets ready to report its second quarter results on Thursday, March 22, 2012. Analysts are expecting the company to book a profit of 86 cents a share, up from 75 cents a year ago.What to Expect:Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has risen from 85 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $3.81 per share for the fiscal year.Revenue is expected to be $6.63 billion for the quarter, 2.1% higher than the year-earlier total of $6.5 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $27.66 billion.Trends to Watch For:Revenue has grown by double digits year-over-year for the last four quarters. Over that time span, revenue has increased by an average of 19.5%, with the largest growth in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year when it rose 23% year-over-year.
The company's profit has been on the rise for three quarters in a row. The 20.1% year-over-year growth in net income in the most recent quarter came after the 37.4% profit growth in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and the 28% rise in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.Analyst Ratings:The majority of analysts (70%) rate Accenture as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 52.4% buys. Analyst sentiment has waned during the last three months.Competitors:Accenture is a global company engaged in management consulting, technology services, and outsourcing. One of Accenture's main competitors in the it services industry is Infosys Technologies (INFY). Other competitors in the information technology sector include: Genpact (G) and Towers Watson (TW).Recent Price Movement:

Analysts expect disappointing news from Forest Laboratories (FRX) when it reports its third quarter earnings on Tuesday, January 15, 2013. They project a loss of -13 cents a share after the company booked a profit of $1.04 a year ago.Analysts are expecting a loss of 13 cents per share, a swing from a profit of $1.04 a year ago.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was 14 cents. The quarter hit the hardest was the most recent quarter, that saw a 91.7% drop.

Wall Street is optimistic about Wells Fargo (WFC), which is slated to report its fourth quarter results on Friday, January 11, 2013. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $3.35 per share. A year after being $22.09 billion, analysts expect revenue to fall 3.6% year-over-year to $21.29 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $85.69 billion.The company's net income has been increasing for three consecutive quarters. In the third quarter, net income rose 21.8% while it rose 17.1% in the second quarter and 13% in the first quarter.The company's reported revenue has increased in the last three quarters. In third quarter, revenue rose 5.7% to $22.48 billion while the figure rose 2.3% in the second quarter from the year earlier and 3.9% in the first quarter.The majority of analysts (63%) rate Wells as a buy. Constellation Brands (STZ) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, January 9, 2013.The Wall Street consensus is 55 cents per share, up 5.8% from a year ago when Constellation Brands reported earnings of 52 cents per share.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was 59 cents. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $2.08 per share. Revenue is projected to eclipse the year-earlier total of $700.7 million by 7.3%, finishing at $751.8 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $2.75 billion.A year-over-year revenue increase in the second quarter came after three straight quarters of falling revenue. The company reported an increase in revenue by 1.2% in the most recent quarter. Going back further, revenue dropped 0.1% in the first quarter, 12.2% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and 27.5% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has seen steady earnings for the last eight quarters, but income has been sliding year-over-year by an average of 28.7% over the last four quarters. The company weathered a blow in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year when net income dropped 63.2%, marking the hardest-hit quarter.
The majority of analysts (80%) rate Constellation Brands as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest six competitors, which average 43.8% buys. Constellation Brands' average analyst rating hasn't changed over the past three months. Still, stock price has risen from $36.35 on October 8, 2012 to $36.63 over the past quarter.

Analyst Ratings:The majority of analysts (52.9%) rate Kroger as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 34.6% buys. Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months.Competitors:Kroger operates food and drug stores, multi-department stores, jewelry stores, and convenience stores in the United States. Other competitors in the consumer staples sector include: SUPERVALU (SVU), Fresh Market (TFM), and Winn-Dixie Stores (WINN).Recent Price Movement:

 reports its third quarter earnings on Thursday, October 17, 2013, and the consensus earnings per share estimate is 71 cents per share.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has fallen from 72 cents. The biggest increase came in the fourth quarter, when income rose 37% from the year-earlier quarter.

 reports its third quarter earnings on Thursday, October 17, 2013, and the consensus earnings per share estimate is $1.53 per share.Over the past month, the consensus estimate has jumped from $1.52, but it's below the estimate of $1.55 from three months ago. In the fourth quarter, the company saw its greatest gain in income, when it increased 7% from the year-earlier quarter.

For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $3.47 billion.Trends to Watch For:Revenue has grown by double digits year-over-year for the last four quarters. Over that span, the company has averaged growth of 17.2%, with the biggest boost coming in the second quarter when revenue rose 22.7% from the year earlier quarter.
While the company has been profitable for the last eight quarters, income has fallen year-over-year by an average of 0.3% over the past four quarters. The quarter hit the hardest was the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, that saw a 30.3% drop.Analyst Ratings:Analysts are split on Expedia, but six of 16 analysts rate it hold.Recent Price Movement:

Analysts are projecting earnings of $27.09 per share for the fiscal year. Analysts project revenue to fall 3.8% year-over-year to $1.35 billion for the quarter, after being $1.4 billion a year ago. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $6.19 billion.The company's profit has been on the rise for three quarters in a row. In the most recent quarter, profit increased 24.4% year-over-year. Going back two quarters, net income rose 30.6% in the first quarter and more than twofold in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.Revenue dropped year-over-year in the second quarter, breaking the three-quarter streak of revenue growth. Revenue fell 3.7% in the second quarter and rose 30.1%in the first quarter, 38.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and 53.1% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.
The majority of analysts (75%) rate CF as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest seven competitors, which average 56.8% buys. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. The stock price has thus risen from $194.39 on August 2, 2012 to $204.82 over the past quarter.CF's current dividend yield is 0.8% based on Monday's close of $205.19. The company has an annualized dividend of $1.60 per share.

Trends to Watch For:The company has seen double-digit year-over-year revenue growth for the past four quarters. Net income rose 63.9% in the quarter before that, and more than twofold in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.Competitors:Mosaic produces and markets concentrated phosphate and potash crop nutrients for the global agriculture industry. One of Mosaic's main competitors in the chemicals industry is PotashCorp (POT). Other competitors in the materials sector include: Agrium, Inc. (USA (AGU), CF Industries Holdings (CF), and Intrepid Potash (IPI).Recent Price Movement:

Analysts are projecting earnings of $3.18 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be 4.8% above the year-earlier total of $1.21 billion at $1.27 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $4.51 billion.Profit rose in the second quarter, breaking a streak of two straight quarters of falling profit. In the most recent quarter, net income increased 12.3%. Going back two more quarters, the company saw profit decreases:55.6% in the first quarter and 29.1% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.All nine analysts rate Wyndham as a buy. Wyndham's average analyst rating hasn't changed over the past three months. Even so, over the past quarter the stock price has increased from $49.34 on July 23, 2012 to $54.87.

DTE Energy (DTE) reports its third quarter earnings on Wednesday, October 24, 2012.The Wall Street consensus is $1.13 per share, up 5.6% from a year ago when DTE Energy reported earnings of $1.07 per share.The consensus estimate has risen from three months ago when it was $1.11. Going back two quarters, profit decreased 11.4% in the first quarter and 1.3% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The company has experienced dips in revenue in the last two quarters. In second quarter, revenue was $2.02 billion, 0.1% lower than the year-ago figure. In the quarter before that, revenue fell 7.5%.

The 2.8% year-over-year growth in net income in the most recent quarter came after the 1.3% profit growth in the first quarter and the 10.3% rise in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.Most analysts think investors should stand pat on Omnicom Group, with 11 of 17 analysts rating it hold. Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months. The stock price has increased from $48.55 on July 13, 2012 to $51.75 over the past quarter.

In spite of an expected dip in profit, most analysts are positive about Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) before it reports its third quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 16, 2012.Analysts are expecting Johnson & Johnson to come in with earnings of $1.21 per share, 2.4% less than a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.24 per share.The consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was $1.25, but is unchanged over the past month. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $5.06 per share. Revenue is projected to be 5.8% above the year-earlier total of $16 billion at $16.93 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $67.17 billion.While being profitable for the last eight quarters, the company has seen net income slip over the past four quarters by an average of 33% year-over-year. The company was hit the hardest in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year as it saw profit drop by 88.8%.The company's reported revenue has declined in the last two quarters. In second quarter, revenue was $16.48 billion, 0.7% lower than the year-ago figure. In the quarter before that, revenue fell 0.2%.

Leading up to Goldman Sachs Group's (GS) announcement of its third quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 16, 2012, analysts have become more bullish as expectations have improved over the past month from $2.10 per share to the current projection of earnings of $2.19 per share.The average analyst estimates earnings to come in at $2.19 per share, a reversal from a loss of 84 cents from a year ago.Over the past three months, the consensus estimate has risen from $2.05. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $11.07 per share. Revenue is projected to eclipse the year-earlier total of $5.58 billion by 28.9%, finishing at $7.2 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $31.3 billion.The company has seen decreasing revenue for four quarters in a row. Revenue declined 10% to $8.59 billion in second quarter. The figure fell 13.5% in the first quarter from the year earlier, dropped 22.7% in fourth quarter of the last fiscal year from the year-ago quarter and 47.9% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.The majority of analysts think investors should stand pat on Goldman, with 12 of 20 analysts rating it hold. Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. Consequently, over the past quarter the stock price has increased from $97.43 on July 13, 2012 to $120.08.

In spite of an expected dip in profit, most analysts are positive about Apollo Group (APOL) before it reports its fourth quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 16, 2012.Analysts are projecting Apollo to come in with earnings of 49 cents per share, down 52% from a year ago when it reported earnings of $1.02 per share.For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $3.57 per share. A year after being $1.12 billion, analysts expect revenue to fall 10% year-over-year to $1.01 billion for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $4.29 billion.

UnitedHealth Group (UNH) reports its third quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 16, 2012.The consensus estimate is $1.25 per share, up 6.8% from a year ago when UnitedHealth reported earnings of $1.17 per share.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was $1.27. Analysts are projecting earnings of $5.04 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is expected to be $27.58 billion for the quarter, 9.1% higher than the year-earlier total of $25.28 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $110.01 billion.The company has reported increasing profit for three straight quarters. In the most recent quarter, net income rose by 5.5% from the year-earlier period. Net income rose 3.1% in the quarter before that, and 20.6% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.The majority of analysts (77.8%) rate UnitedHealth as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 43.8% buys. Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months. The stock price has thus risen from $55.20 on July 13, 2012 to $57.11 over the past quarter.

Analysts are looking for decreased profit for Linear Technology (LLTC) when the company reports its results for the first quarter on Tuesday, October 16, 2012. Linear Technology reported profit of 48 cents a year ago, but the consensus estimate calls for earnings per share of 46 cents this time around.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was 48 cents. Analysts are expecting earnings of $1.92 per share for the fiscal year. Revenue is projected to be $331.3 million for the quarter, 0.4% above the year-earlier total of $329.9 million. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $1.27 billion.The company's reported revenue has declined in each of the last four quarters. In fourth quarter of the last fiscal year, revenue fell 8% to $330 million. Prior to that, the figure declined 11.6% year-over-year in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, fell 23.3% in second quarter of the last fiscal year and slid 15.1% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.Analyst sentiment has improved recently, as the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. The stock price has increased from $30.10 on July 13, 2012 to $31.61 over the past quarter.

Wall Street is high on Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), expecting it to report earnings that are up 14.1% from a year ago when it reports its third quarter earnings on Tuesday, October 16, 2012. The consensus estimate is $3.48 per share, up from earnings of $3.05 per share a year ago.The consensus estimate remains unchanged over the past month, but it has decreased from three months ago when it was $3.61. For the fiscal year, analysts are projecting earnings of $14.81 per share. Revenue is projected to be 19.7% above the year-earlier total of $446.7 million at $534.9 million for the quarter. For the year, revenue is projected to roll in at $2.16 billion.The company has enjoyed double-digit year-over-year percentage revenue growth for the past four quarters. Over that period, revenue has grown by an average of 27.7%. The biggest boost came in the third quarter of the last fiscal year when revenue increased 29.7% year-over-year.The company's net income has been growing for three straight quarters. In the second quarter, net income rose 31.9% while it rose 37.8% in the first quarter and 24.8% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.

In the month leading up to the JPMorgan Chase's (JPM) third quarter earnings announcement slated for Friday, July 13, 2012, expectations have risen for the upcoming results. The consensus analyst estimate has gone from $1.16 per share to the current projection of earnings of $1.21 per share.Analysts' estimates are up 18.6% from the year-ago quarter, when JPMorgan reported earnings of $1.02 per share.The consensus estimate has gone up, from $1.04, over the past three months. Analysts are expecting earnings of $4.74 per share for the fiscal year. For the year, revenue is expected to come in at $97.76 billion.Revenue fell in the second quarter after seeing a rise the quarter before. Revenue dropped 17.8% to $25.13 billion in the second quarter from the year earlier. In the first quarter, revenue rose 3.4%.The majority of analysts (68%) rate JPMorgan as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 50% buys. Analysts have become more optimistic about the stock recently and the number of buy ratings has risen slightly over the past three months. Consequently, over the past quarter the stock price has increased from $34.59 on July 11, 2012 to $41.66.
JPMorgan's current dividend yield is 2.9% based on Friday's close of $41.45. The company has an annualized dividend of $1.20 per share.

Optimism surrounds Wells Fargo (WFC), as it gets ready to report its third quarter results on Friday, October 12, 2012. It hasn't been adjusted since. For the fiscal year, analysts are expecting earnings of $3.33 per share. Revenue is projected to be $21.45 billion for the quarter, 0.9% above the year-earlier total of $21.26 billion. For the year, revenue is projected to come in at $85.47 billion.The company has posted increasing profit for three quarters in a row. In the most recent quarter, revenue rose 2.3% year-over-year to $22.61 billion. The quarter before that, it rose 3.9%.The majority of analysts (76.9%) rate Wells as a buy. This compares favorably to the analyst ratings of its nearest 10 competitors, which average 50% buys. Analysts have grown increasingly optimistic about the stock in the last three months. The stock price has thus risen from $33.27 on July 11, 2012 to $35.80 over the past quarter.

Wall Street is optimistic about Yum! Brands (YUM), which is slated to report its third quarter results on Tuesday, October 9, 2012. In the most recent quarter, net income rose by 4.7% from the year-earlier period. Net income rose 73.5% in the quarter before that, and 29.9% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year.

Looking back further, revenue increased 8.6% year-over-year in the third quarter of the last fiscal year, 10.3% in the second quarter of the last fiscal year, and 12.7% in the first quarter of the last fiscal year.Competitors:AutoZone is a retailer and distributor of automotive parts and accessories. Trends to Watch For:A year-over-year drop in revenue in the second quarter broke a three-quarter streak of revenue increases. Revenue fell 7.1% in the second quarter and rose 0.1%in the first quarter, 3.2% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and 3.8% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.The profit dip in the second quarter came after three consecutive quarters of rising profit. Net income fell 5.8% in the second quarter from the year earlier, while the figure rose 4.8% in the first quarter, 7.3% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year and 27.4% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.Competitors:SAIC provides the U.S. military and other government entities with scientific, engineering, systems integration, and technical services and solutions. One of SAIC's main competitors in the electronic equipment, instruments and components industry is OSI Systems (OSIS). Analysts are looking for decreased profit for Kroger (KR) when the company reports its results for the third quarter on Thursday, December 1, 2011. Analyst sentiment has been waning recently, as the number of buy ratings has dropped slightly over the past three months.
Trends to Watch For:The company has seen rising revenue for the past four quarters. Revenue increased 11.3% to $20.91 billion in the second quarter. Revenue rose 10.9% in the first quarter from the year earlier, climbed 7.6% in the fourth quarter of the last fiscal year from the year-ago quarter and 5.8% in the third quarter of the last fiscal year.Competitors:Kroger operates food and drug stores, multi-department stores, jewelry stores, and convenience stores in the United States. It also manufactures and processes some of the food for sale in its supermarkets. One of Kroger's main competitors in the food and staples retailing industry is Delhaize Group (DEG). Other competitors in the consumer staples sector include: Safeway (SWY), SUPERVALU (SVU), and Fresh Market (TFM).Recent Price Movement:

Analysts have become increasingly bullish on Aeropostale (ARO) in the month leading up to the company's third quarter earnings announcement scheduled for Wednesday, November 30, 2011. Trends to Watch For:A drop in revenue in the second quarter came after three straight quarters of rising revenue. The 5.4% revenue decline in the most recent quarter can be compared with three quarters prior when it had been rising. The company was hit the hardest in the most recent quarter as its net income dropped by 93.3%.Competitors:Aeropostale is a mall-based specialty retailer of casual apparel and accessories. One of Aeropostale's main competitors in the specialty retail industry is Gap (GPS). Other competitors in the consumer discretionary sector include: Pacific Sunwear of California (PSUN), Zumiez (ZUMZ), and Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF).Recent Price Movement:

Despite an expected dip in profit, analysts are generally optimistic about Constellation Brands (STZ) as it prepares to reports its second quarter earnings on Friday, October 5, 2012.Analysts are expecting Constellation Brands to come in with earnings of 54 cents per share, down 29.9% from a year ago when it reported earnings of 77 cents per share.Despite not changing over the past month, the consensus estimate is down from three months ago when it was 57 cents. , Inc. reports its second quarter earnings on Tuesday, August 6, 2013, and the consensus earnings per share estimate is 93 cents per share.The consensus estimate hasn't changed over the past month, but it's down from three months ago when it was $1.05.
